speaker: PORTIA
text: By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary

speaker: PORTIA
text: of this great world.

speaker: NERISSA
text: You would be, sweet madam, if your miseries

speaker: NERISSA
text: were in the same abundance as your good fortunes

speaker: NERISSA
text: are. And yet, for aught I see, they are as sick that

speaker: NERISSA
text: surfeit with too much as they that starve with

speaker: NERISSA
text: nothing. It is no mean happiness, therefore, to be

speaker: NERISSA
text: seated in the mean. Superfluity comes sooner by

speaker: NERISSA
text: white hairs, but competency lives longer.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Good sentences, and well pronounced.

speaker: NERISSA
text: They would be better if well followed.

speaker: PORTIA
text: If to do were as easy as to know what were

speaker: PORTIA
text: good to do, chapels had been churches, and poor

speaker: PORTIA
text: men’s cottages princes’ palaces. It is a good divine

speaker: PORTIA
text: that follows his own instructions. I can easier teach

speaker: PORTIA
text: twenty what were good to be done than to be one of

speaker: PORTIA
text: the twenty to follow mine own teaching. The brain

speaker: PORTIA
text: may devise laws for the blood, but a hot temper

speaker: PORTIA
text: leaps o’er a cold decree: such a hare is madness the

speaker: PORTIA
text: youth, to skip o’er the meshes of good counsel the

speaker: PORTIA
text: cripple. But this reasoning is not in the fashion to

speaker: PORTIA
text: choose me a husband. O, me, the word “choose”! I

speaker: PORTIA
text: may neither choose who I would nor refuse who I

speaker: PORTIA
text: dislike. So is the will of a living daughter curbed by

speaker: PORTIA
text: the will of a dead father. Is it not hard, Nerissa, that

speaker: PORTIA
text: I cannot choose one, nor refuse none?

speaker: NERISSA
text: Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men

speaker: NERISSA
text: at their death have good inspirations. Therefore the

speaker: NERISSA
text: lottery that he hath devised in these three chests of

speaker: NERISSA
text: gold, silver, and lead, whereof who chooses his

speaker: NERISSA
text: meaning chooses you, will no doubt never be

speaker: NERISSA
text: chosen by any rightly but one who you shall rightly

speaker: NERISSA
text: love. But what warmth is there in your affection

speaker: NERISSA
text: towards any of these princely suitors that are already

speaker: NERISSA
text: come?

speaker: PORTIA
text: I pray thee, overname them, and as thou

speaker: PORTIA
text: namest them, I will describe them, and according

speaker: PORTIA
text: to my description level at my affection.

speaker: NERISSA
text: First, there is the Neapolitan prince.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Ay, that’s a colt indeed, for he doth nothing but

speaker: PORTIA
text: talk of his horse, and he makes it a great appropriation

speaker: PORTIA
text: to his own good parts that he can shoe him

speaker: PORTIA
text: himself. I am much afeard my lady his mother

speaker: PORTIA
text: played false with a smith.

speaker: NERISSA
text: Then is there the County Palatine.

speaker: PORTIA
text: He doth nothing but frown, as who should say

speaker: PORTIA
text: “An you will not have me, choose.” He hears

speaker: PORTIA
text: merry tales and smiles not. I fear he will prove the

speaker: PORTIA
text: weeping philosopher when he grows old, being so

speaker: PORTIA
text: full of unmannerly sadness in his youth. I had

speaker: PORTIA
text: rather be married to a death’s-head with a bone in

speaker: PORTIA
text: his mouth than to either of these. God defend me

speaker: PORTIA
text: from these two!

speaker: NERISSA
text: How say you by the French lord, Monsieur Le

speaker: NERISSA
text: Bon?

speaker: PORTIA
text: God made him, and therefore let him pass for

speaker: PORTIA
text: a man. In truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker,

speaker: PORTIA
text: but he!—why, he hath a horse better than the

speaker: PORTIA
text: Neapolitan’s, a better bad habit of frowning than

speaker: PORTIA
text: the Count Palatine. He is every man in no man. If a

speaker: PORTIA
text: throstle sing, he falls straight a-cap’ring. He will

speaker: PORTIA
text: fence with his own shadow. If I should marry him, I

speaker: PORTIA
text: should marry twenty husbands! If he would despise

speaker: PORTIA
text: me, I would forgive him, for if he love me to

speaker: PORTIA
text: madness, I shall never requite him.

speaker: NERISSA
text: What say you then to Falconbridge, the young

speaker: NERISSA
text: baron of England?

speaker: PORTIA
text: You know I say nothing to him, for he understands

speaker: PORTIA
text: not me, nor I him. He hath neither Latin,

speaker: PORTIA
text: French, nor Italian; and you will come into the

speaker: PORTIA
text: court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in

speaker: PORTIA
text: the English. He is a proper man’s picture, but alas,

speaker: PORTIA
text: who can converse with a dumb show? How oddly

speaker: PORTIA
text: he is suited! I think he bought his doublet in Italy,

speaker: PORTIA
text: his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany,

speaker: PORTIA
text: and his behavior everywhere.

speaker: NERISSA
text: What think you of the Scottish lord, his

speaker: NERISSA
text: neighbor?

speaker: PORTIA
text: That he hath a neighborly charity in him, for

speaker: PORTIA
text: he borrowed a box of the ear of the Englishman,

speaker: PORTIA
text: and swore he would pay him again when he was

speaker: PORTIA
text: able. I think the Frenchman became his surety and

speaker: PORTIA
text: sealed under for another.

speaker: NERISSA
text: How like you the young German, the Duke of

speaker: NERISSA
text: Saxony’s nephew?

speaker: PORTIA
text: Very vilely in the morning, when he is sober,

speaker: PORTIA
text: and most vilely in the afternoon, when he is drunk.

speaker: PORTIA
text: When he is best he is a little worse than a man, and

speaker: PORTIA
text: when he is worst he is little better than a beast. An

speaker: PORTIA
text: the worst fall that ever fell, I hope I shall make shift

speaker: PORTIA
text: to go without him.

speaker: NERISSA
text: If he should offer to choose, and choose the

speaker: NERISSA
text: right casket, you should refuse to perform your

speaker: NERISSA
text: father’s will if you should refuse to accept him.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Therefore, for fear of the worst, I pray thee set

speaker: PORTIA
text: a deep glass of Rhenish wine on the contrary

speaker: PORTIA
text: casket, for if the devil be within and that temptation

speaker: PORTIA
text: without, I know he will choose it. I will do

speaker: PORTIA
text: anything, Nerissa, ere I will be married to a sponge.

speaker: NERISSA
text: You need not fear, lady, the having any of

speaker: NERISSA
text: these lords. They have acquainted me with their

speaker: NERISSA
text: determinations, which is indeed to return to their

speaker: NERISSA
text: home and to trouble you with no more suit, unless

speaker: NERISSA
text: you may be won by some other sort than your

speaker: NERISSA
text: father’s imposition depending on the caskets.

speaker: PORTIA
text: If I live to be as old as Sibylla, I will die as

speaker: PORTIA
text: chaste as Diana unless I be obtained by the manner

speaker: PORTIA
text: of my father’s will. I am glad this parcel of wooers

speaker: PORTIA
text: are so reasonable, for there is not one among them

speaker: PORTIA
text: but I dote on his very absence. And I pray God

speaker: PORTIA
text: grant them a fair departure!

speaker: NERISSA
text: Do you not remember, lady, in your father’s

speaker: NERISSA
text: time, a Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came

speaker: NERISSA
text: hither in company of the Marquess of Montferrat?

speaker: PORTIA
text: Yes, yes, it was Bassanio—as I think so was he

speaker: PORTIA
text: called.

speaker: NERISSA
text: True, madam. He, of all the men that ever my

speaker: NERISSA
text: foolish eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a

speaker: NERISSA
text: fair lady.

speaker: PORTIA
text: I remember him well, and I remember him

speaker: PORTIA
text: worthy of thy praise.

speaker: PORTIA
text: How now, what news?

speaker: SERVINGMAN
text: The four strangers seek for you, madam,

speaker: SERVINGMAN
text: to take their leave. And there is a forerunner come

speaker: SERVINGMAN
text: from a fifth, the Prince of Morocco, who brings

speaker: SERVINGMAN
text: word the Prince his master will be here tonight.

speaker: PORTIA
text: If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good

speaker: PORTIA
text: heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should

speaker: PORTIA
text: be glad of his approach. If he have the condition of

speaker: PORTIA
text: a saint and the complexion of a devil, I had rather

speaker: PORTIA
text: he should shrive me than wive me.

speaker: PORTIA
text:
Come
              ,
               
              Nerissa
              .
              
                 
                To
                 
                Servingman
                .
              
               
              Sirrah
              ,
               
              go
               
              before
              .
              —

speaker: PORTIA
text:
Whiles
               
              we
               
              shut
               
              the
               
              gate
               
              upon
               
              one
               
              wooer
              ,
               
              another
               
              knocks
               
              at
               
              the
               
              door
              .
